content.text: On Fig. 1.1, measure the length \(l\) of the pendulum
The pendulum is drawn 1/10th of actual size
Write the actual length of the pendulum in the first row of Table 1.1
Calculate the period \(T\) of the pendulum. The period is the time for one complete oscillation
Record the value of \(T\) in Table 1.1
Complete the column headings in the table
A student displaces the pendulum bob slightly and releases it so that it swings
Fig. 1.2 shows one complete oscillation of the pendulum bob
The student uses a stopwatch to record the time \(t\) for 20 complete oscillations of the pendulum. The reading is recorded in the table
The student adjusts the length of the pendulum until its length \(l = 61.9 \text{cm}\). He the procedure in **(b)** and calculates \(T\). The results are shown in Table 1.1
The student suggests that doubling the length \(l\) of the pendulum should double the period \(T\)
State whether the results support this suggestion and justify your answer by reference to the results
statement
justification
The student repeats the procedure in **(b)** four more times with different lengths of the pendulum
The student plots a graph of \(l\) against \(T^2\)
State two pieces of information from the graph that would indicate that \(l\) is directly proportional to \(T^2\)
The student uses another pendulum
This pendulum has a mass that is double the mass of the first pendulum. Its length is \(61.9 \text{cm}\). The period \(T = 1.61 \text{s}\)
Suggest a conclusion about the effect of doubling the mass of the pendulum
The IGCSE class is investigating pendulums
The apparatus is shown in Figs. 1.1 and 1.2
The student pours approximately \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into a beaker
She measures the temperature \(\theta_{1}\). Fig. 2.1 shows the thermometer
Write down the temperature \(\theta_{1}\) shown on the thermometer in Fig. 2.1
Write down the temperature \(\theta_{2}\) shown on the thermometer in Fig. 2.2
Calculate the temperature difference \((\theta_{1} - \theta_{2})\)
The student stirs the water for one minute. She then records the temperature \(\theta_{2}\) of the water
Write down the temperature \(\theta_{3}\) shown on the thermometer in Fig. 2.3
Calculate the temperature difference \((\theta_{1} - \theta_{3})\)
Experiment C (cooling with a lid) and Experiment D (cooling without a lid)
The student starts again with approximately \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water at the same initial temperature \(\theta_{1}\)
The student pours approximately \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of the hot water into each of two beakers. The initial temperature of the water in each beaker is \(\theta_1\)
She places a lid on one of the beakers. She allows both beakers to cool for 5 minutes
At the end of the cooling period, she calculates the temperature differences
Rank the experiments \(\mathbf{A}, \mathbf{B}, \mathbf{C}\) and \(\mathbf{D}\) in order, with the one that produced the greatest temperature drop first
greatest temperature drop 1
smallest temperature drop 4
If this laboratory investigation is to be repeated many times to check the results, suggest two conditions that should be kept constant in order to provide reliable results
A student complains that the investigation is not a fair comparison
Suggest one way in which the investigation could be more fair
The IGCSE class is investigating the cooling of water
A student cools some water by four different methods
**Experiment A (cooling with stirring)**
He measures the current \(I\) in the wire. Fig. 3.2 shows the ammeter
Record the value of \(I\)
The student measures the potential difference \(V\) across the wire between \(\mathbf{A}\) and \(\mathbf{C}\). Fig. 3.3 shows the voltmeter
Calculate the resistance \(R\) of the section \(\mathbf{AC}\) of the wire using the equation
Record \(R\) in the first row of the table
A student places the sliding contact \(\mathbf{C}\) on the resistance wire \(\mathbf{AB}\) at a distance \(x\) from \(\mathbf{A}\), where \(x = 0.200 \text{m}\)
The student records the voltmeter readings using a range of \(x\) values. The readings are shown in Table 3.1
Plot a graph of \(R / \Omega\) ( \(y\)-axis) against \(x / \text{m}\) ( \(x\)-axis)
Using your graph, determine the length \(l\) of the resistance wire necessary to
a resistor of resistance \(1.20\Omega\). Show clearly on your graph how you obtained necessary information
Predict the resistance \(Z\) of \(1.50 \text{m}\) of the resistance wire. Show your working
The IGCSE class is investigating the resistance of a wire
The circuit used is shown in Fig. 3.1
On Fig. 4.1, measure and record the distance \(u\), in mm, between the illuminated object and the lens
Measure and record the distance \(v\), in mm, from the centre of the lens to the image on the screen
Calculate the value of \(uv\)
Calculate the value of \((u + v)\)
Calculate a value \(f_{\mathrm{I}}\) for the focal length of the lens, using the equation \(f_{\mathrm{I}} = \frac{uv}{(u + v)}\)
\(f_{\mathrm{I}} =\)
Calculate the value of \(uv\)
Calculate the value of \((u + v)\)
Calculate a second value \(f_{2}\) for the focal length of the lens, using the equation
A student does not move the position of the screen or the illuminated object. She moves the lens towards the screen until a smaller, sharply focused image of the object is seen on the screen
The new values of \(u\) and \(v\) are
A student suggests that \(f_{1}\) should be equal to \(f_{2}\)
State whether the results support this suggestion. Justify your answer by reference to the results
statement
justification
State two precautions that you could take in this experiment to obtain reliable results
The illuminated object is triangular, as shown in Fig. 4.2
Sketch the image you would see on the screen
The IGCSE class is determining the focal length of a converging lens
Fig. 4.1 shows the apparatus
On Fig. 5.1, measure the length \(x\) of the block
On Fig. 5.1, measure the width \(y\) of the block
Using Fig. 5.2, write down the weight \(W\) of the block
Fig. 5.2
Calculate the pressure \(P\) that the block exerts on the bench. Use the equation \(P = \frac{W}{A}\) where \(A\) is the area of the block in contact with the bench \((A = xy)\)
P =
Fig. 5.2 shows the block being weighed using a forcemeter
The value calculated for \(P\) is slightly too small
Suggest one practical source of inaccuracy that would account for this
The IGCSE class is investigating pressure
A student places a rectangular block on a sheet of paper on the bench and draws the outline
Fig. 5.1 shows the outline
